Comment: One of the more interesting modern openings to study, the Grünfeld Defence is one to truly test one's abilities. It is very active and tactical due to the open nature of the position. Naturally, there is the danger that White's big center will lead to a strong attack. Yet by sidestepping the pawn steamroller and attacking it, Black can feel relatively secure. White may have the center, but Black can chip away at it from the supports by playing ...Bg4, moving the Knight from f6, and acting on the Queenside. Enough small talk though, on with the action!

Naturally, White is pleased at the prospect of exchanging a flank pawn, the c4-pawn, for Black's central pawn

This is the starting position for the Grunfeld Exchange Variation. Naturally, White is very pleased with himself. He has established a classical center in exactly half a dozen moves. Classical players are cheering! But, Black isn't about to give up the game now. He reasons that after fianchettoing his Bishop, he will be able to put strong pressure on White's d4-pawn and the long diagonal

Black plans the counter ...c7-c5 and ...Nb8-c6 to attack the d4-pawn. White must make a crucial decision as how he should defend his center. Would he like his Knight defending his d4-pawn on the e2 or f3-square? While the f3-square is preferable, the Knight would then be vulnerable to a pin from the c8-Bishop.
This development move allows my knight to come to e2, without worrying about Bg4 as much (compare to f3)
And the counter-assault on the center ensues
While I am a turn up in development, Black has a more solid pawn structure. So I would argue almost full equality at this point.

?! - Here I decide to make a positional sacrifice. Remove the active bishop from the equation and try and control as many squares as possible with my bishop pair. Again, a lot of smoke is fired here, let's evaluate after the dust has settled...

So here's the situation: we both have our queens, pretty active (though his is more tied to defense to keep his pawn defended), he has a rook that is not in the game at the moment, and a bishop that is quite limited. I have the bishop pair and a knight and an isolated pawn. Does either side really have an advantage?

?! - Very interesting. I was not expecting this trade right away since he is a pawn up. This endgame is becoming more and more interesting each turn.

Black's goal, keep that rook and try and get one of my bishops off. Anyone who knows their endgames knows that R+P usually is not enough to win against 2 B. This depends on many other factors though!
